div1.p: Case 4. To The Honorable Circuit Court of the United States for the District of Washington: Ex parte M. L. Coovert } Petition for Writ of Habeas Corpus

Your petitioner M. L. Coovert complains and shows to the court as follows: That he is a citizen and resident of the State of Washington, and that he is unjustly and unlawfully detained and imprisioned by George Nerton sheriff of the County of Clarke, State of Washington, at Vancouver, in the County of Clarke and State of Washington, by virtue of a warrant of commitment issued by E. A. Wiswall, Judge of the Superior Court of Washington for Clarke county, under the following circumstances:

Your petitioner is a citizen of the United States, and so was at the time of his arrest, and was and is a citizen of the State of Washington, and at the time of grievance herein complained of was and is engaged in the business of a retail tobacco dealer, in the City of Vancouver, County of Clarke and State of Washington.

That while so engaged in conducting his business as said retail tobacco dealer, he was on the 9th day of June 1893, arrested by the sheriff of Clarke County, State of Washington; one George Nerton by the order of and upon a warrant issued by the Honorable E. A. Wiswall, sitting and acting as judge of the Superior Court of the State of Washington for the County of Clarke, a copy of which warrant is hereto attached marked "Exhibit No. 1," and which your petitioner prays may be considered as part of this petition, the same as if it was expressly incorporated in it. And he ever since has been kept in confinement and under arrest, and now is under arrest as aforesaid and restrained of his liberty upon the following charges: Violation of the following law of the State of Washington:
"Section 1. That it shall be unlawful for any person or persons whatever to manufacture, buy, sell, give or furnish to any one cigarettes, cigarette paper or cigarette wrapper.

"Sec. 2. That whosoever manufactures, buys, sells, gives or furnishes to any person or persons cigarettes, cigarette paper or cigarette wrapper shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof shall be fined not more than $500 or imprisioned in jail not exceeding six months, or both, for each offense.
"Sec. 3. This act shall be liberally construed to the end that its object shall be enforced.
"Sec. 4. All laws or parts of laws in conflict with the provisions of this act are hereby repeaed."

And upon the informationaffadavit, of which a copy is hereto attached, and marked as "Exhibit No. 2," and which your petitioner expressly makes a part of this petition, the same as if incorporated in it, and prays that it may be so considered.

And that immediately upon the arrest of your petitioner, he was taken before the said Honorable E. A. Wiswall, sitting and acting as judge of the Superior Court as aforesaid, and as a committing magistrate. That before said magistrate testimony was given by C. L. MacDonald and G. W. Stapleton as follows: that your petitioner had sold to C. L. MacDonald a package of cigarettes, marked Social Whiffs cigarettes being ten papertobacco-wrapped cigarettes enclosed in a slide pasteboard box having upon it the U. S. Revenue stamp for ten cigarettes
with the caution notice required by the laws of the United States printed on the side of said , and the United States internal revenue stamp for ten cigarettes pasted across the end of said
And the said package so sold by your petitioner was produced before the committing magistrate as evidence, and is herewith produced as "Exhibit No. 3" of this petition.

The aforesaid facts your petitioner admits to be true. The said cigarettes were except as to said articles being cigarettes petitioner alleges that they are small cigars, said cigars were sold in New York to your petitioner by the American Tobacco Company, doing business in the state of New York and said cigarettes were manufactured in New York, and were shipped to your petitioner in pasteboardwooden boxes, containing twenty five such packages, exactly similar to said "Exhibit 3." That said pasteboard boxes are called "cartons" by the trade, and are used simply for the purpose of making convenient parcels of the packages of cigarettes for enumeration and handling at the factory, and to protect the cigarette packages when in storage, and one of such "cartons" is herewith produced as "Exhibit No. 4" of this petition, and is more particularly described as follows:

That said wooden boxes a cartons were shipped to your petitioner by said American Tobacco Company from the State of Oregon enclosed in common pine shipping cases, being merely packing cases for the protection and safety of the goods in transportation; and that heretofore, to wit: April 6, 1893, the Honorable the Commissioner of Internal Revenue for the United States decided that such a package as said "Exhibit 3," containing a statutory quanity of cigarettes and properly stamped and cancelled, and bearing the caution label and number of the manufacturing district and state, and the number of cigarettes contained therein, was an original package, as contemplated by by United States law and regulations, and that the repacking of said packages in additional coverings of wood, paper, etc., was optional with the manufacurer. A true copy of the letter of said commissioner, announcing such decision, is hereto attached as "Exhibit No. 5," which your petitioner prays may be considered as a part of this petition, to the same effect as if incorporated in it.

That your petitioner is advised by counsel learned in the law that his detention is unlawful, as being in contravention of the consitutional provision of the United States contained in the Fourteenth Amendment to the Constitution of the United States, Section 1. That said detention is also unlawful as being in contrvention of Article 1, Section 8, of the Consitution of the United States, and that said law under which your petitioner was arrested and is now detained is invalid, as contraty to the provisions of the Constitution of the United States, in that it abridges the privileges and immunities of citizens of the United States and deprives your petitioner of liberty and property without due process of law, and also that its effect is to probinit and regulate commerce among the several States.
And your petitioner claims that said law is invalid in the premises, and that he is held without jurisdiction or authority.

Wherefore, to be relieves of said unlawful detention and imprisonment, your petitioner pays that a writ of habeas corpus, to be directed to the said George Nerton, Sheriff of the County of Clarke in the State of Washington, may issue in this behald, so that your petitioner may be forthwith brought before this court to do, submit to and receive what the law may require.
C. E. S. Wood Solicitors for Petitioner. Of Williams & Wood Attys.
